description: Starting at the historic crossing point of the river Ravensbourne we will walk north towards the Thames, revealing unique and uncommon vestiges of Deptford’s remarkable history. Organised by the Deptford Society.

events.name: Walk through historic Deptford
events.notes: This guided walk is organised by the Deptford Society and will feature some of the architectural and historical highlights of the Deptford High Street & St Paul's conservation area.

factsheet.heading: Deptford High St & St Paul's Conservation area
paragraphs: The Deptford High Street and St Paul’s Church Conservation Area is one of the most distinctive in London. Its tangible spirit of place springs from a blend of its unique history, the vitality of its historic retail and market character, and the scale, grain and texture of its buildings and townscape. Because of development pressure and the changing nature of shopping, this special interest is fragile and vulnerable.

factsheet.heading: Historical interest
paragraphs:
The Conservation Area encompasses the historic settlement of Upper Deptford. This was centred on a widening of the former Roman Road to Canterbury (now A2) known as the
Broadway, and the High Street, which connected the Broadway to the riverside settlement and former Royal Naval dockyard. Where it survives, archaeological evidence of this past is important.

• Deptford was a town quite separate from London, and one that in the early 18th century was larger than most cities in England. Street patterns, narrow plot boundaries and surviving historic buildings are evidence of this past and of the evolution of the community and the lives of the people who have formed it.

• Postwar redevelopment has created a new sense of distinctiveness. This is expressed in the stark difference between the historic buildings and townscape of the Conservation Area and the style and layout of postwar housing beyond its boundaries.

factsheet.heading: Architectural interest
paragraphs: There are dozens of modest pre-1800 buildings, of types once common in London but now very rare. Many are hidden behind later or altered frontages and are little understood, but their existence, character and historic fabric is of the highest significance in contributing to the Conservation Area’s special interest.

• There are also several buildings and shopfronts dating to the first half of the 20th century, such as the 1930s Art Deco former Burton’s the Tailors store (Nos. 9-12 Deptford Broadway), the mid-20th century chrome shopfront at 53 Deptford Broadway (corner of Tanners Hill) and the 1920s moderne style tile-clad former Salvation Army shop, (No. 144a Deptford High Street) which expand the range and type of retail architecture in the area.
• Scale, grain and texture are fundamental to what makes the townscape and architecture of the Conservation Area distinctive and significant, in the following ways:

factsheet.heading: Social and cultural character
paragraphs: The continued vitality of the High Street as a bustling retail centre, characterised by an unusually high proportion of small independent retailers and the popular markets, is central to the distinctive character of the Conservation Area.
• Shops and market serve a wide range of communities- the interaction and cultural and social energy of these communities strengthen the character of the area.
• Residential use above shops and in side streets- the other function that contributes strongly to the character and appearance of the Conservation Area.

location.address: South exit of Deptford Bridge DLR station at ground level, SE8 4HP
travel_info: Nearest tube: Deptford Bridge, New Cross, Greenwich
Nearest train: Deptford, New Cross, Greenwich

name: Historic Deptford – a walk from the Creek to the Thames
